intro: Trihaloragis hexandra, commonly known as the six-angled waterwheel, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible parts. The plant is characterized by its whorled arrangement of leaves and small, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring. Its name "hexandra" refers to the six-part structure of its flowers, a key botanical feature. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found near water sources in its natural habitat.
